question: Please describe in no more than 200 words the following:
gtruth_answer: The human developing central nervous system may be more vulnerable to the adverse effects of chemical agents than the adult brain. At present, due to the knowledge gap concerning hazard identification for human neurodevelopmental toxicity (DNT), there is an urgent need for testing and subsequent regulation of chemicals for their potential to interfere with the developing nervous system. Primary human neural progenitor cells (hNPCs) cultivated as three-dimensional floating spheres are able to represent several key processes during brain development. In the neural progenitor cell migration and differentiation assay (NPC2-5), hNPCs are plated on an extracellular matrix, and migrate and differentiate out of the sphere core. Thereby the processes radial glia migration, migration of neurons and oligodendrocytes as well as differentiation into neurons and oligodendrocytes and neurite outgrowth can be studied. Those DNT-specific endpoints are studied in combination with general cell viability and cytotoxicity. Cell migration and differentiation are critical processes during brain development that, if disturbed, lead to alterations in brain development and may cause cognitive dysfunction. Currently, cortical NPC migration- and differentiation-related processes are some of the many processes, which are assessed in the OECD TG426 by neuropathological evaluation of certain brain regions as well as neurobehavioral tests. According to the readiness criteria as published by Bal-Price et al. (2018), the neural progenitor cell migration and differentiation assay obtained readiness scores between A and B depending on the endpoint.
gtruth_answer_quality_justification: The answer provides a detailed description of the vulnerability of the developing central nervous system to chemical agents and the need for testing. It explains the use of human neural progenitor cells in assays to study neurodevelopmental toxicity, mentioning specific processes and endpoints. However, it lacks clarity on how this directly addresses the question, which seems to require a concise description of a specific method or process. The answer is informative but could be more focused and concise to fully meet the question's requirements.
llm_answer: The NPC2-5 assay evaluates human neural progenitor cell (hNPC) migration and differentiation to assess developmental neurotoxicity. In this assay, primary hNPCs isolated from the human fetal cortex are cultured as three‐dimensional neurospheres and then plated on poly-D-lysine/laminin-coated 96-well plates in differentiation medium. Over a period of up to 120 hours, cells migrate radially from the core, differentiating into radial glia, neurons, and oligodendrocytes. Migration is quantified by measuring the distance from the sphere core to the edge of the migration zone using brightfield and immunocytochemical imaging. Additional endpoints include neuronal differentiation (percentage of β-III-tubulin-positive cells), neurite outgrowth (neurite length and area), and oligodendrocyte differentiation (percentage of O4-positive cells). The assay uses automated high-content imaging and analysis software to obtain quantified endpoints while incorporating controls such as PP2, EGF, and BMP7 to validate endpoint-specific responses. This method provides a human-relevant platform for investigating chemical impacts on critical neurodevelopmental processes and is designed for integration in an in vitro developmental neurotoxicity testing battery. (Source: NPC2-5.pdf)

gtruth_answer: The sphere size at day 0 of cell thawing can be different depending on the donor. In the 3- to 4-week expansion period different donors can show differences in their proliferative capacity (spheres need longer, 3 instead of 4 weeks, to reach the acceptable minimum size of 0.2 – 0.5 µm). After the first mechanical dissociation, there are no observable or measurable inter-individual differences. Critical consumables The proliferation medium does not contain serum or serum replacement. The use of epidermal growth factor (EGF) and recombinant human fibroblast growth factor (FGF) is critical for sphere growth. FGF contains 1% bovine serum albumin and is thus prone to batch effects. Critical handling The thawing medium contains DMSO in a concentration that affects cell health which is why thawed cells should quickly be diluted in proliferation medium (30 mL of media for one vial of cells). It is recommended to add FGF into the proliferation medium directly before thawing. At the end of week two of the expansion period (see below), the spheres should be transferred to petri dishes coated with poly-(2-hydroxyethyl methacrylate) (poly-Hema) to prevent cell attachment. Attached cells that are not differentiated can be gently detached using a 1000 µL pipet. To avoid repeated attachment, all cells should be transferred to a new poly-Hema coated petri dish. Medium containing FGF should not be stored longer than 1 week at 4°C. During the first two weeks, the medium should be removed using a 1000 µL pipet to keep the accidental removal of small spheres to a minimum. In addition, removed medium should be kept in a new petri dish under culture conditions until the next feeding day, to transfer accidentally removed spheres back to the culture. The neurospheres should be well distributed in the petri dish to prevent aggregation. This is especially important after mechanical dissociations. question: Give information on where the test system differs from the mimicked human tissue and which gaps of analogy need to be considered.
gtruth_answer: hNPCs reflect the following in vivo tissue features: In differentiation culture: NPC2a – radial glia cell migration → corresponding to radial glia cell migration during corticogenesis in vivo. The migrated hNPCs exhibit the characteristic elongated radial glia (RG)-like morphology and express the RG-markers nestin and GFAP as well as the proliferation marker Ki-67 (Koch et al., 2022). In accordance with in vivo studies, exposure to EGF (0.5-1 ng/mL) after neurosphere plating enhances hNPC migration compared to the solvent control (Koch et al., 2022). As a second human-relevant key regulator of migration, hNPCs respond to SRC-family kinase inhibition (PP2) with reduced migration (Moors et al., 2007; Koch et al., 2022). The migration speed of hNPCs in vitro is in the same range as migrating mouse granule cells in vivo (Baumann et al., 2016, Fahrion et al., 2012). NPC2b – migration of young cortical neurons on radial glia scaffolds → corresponding to cortical neuronal radial migration. NPC2c – oligodendrocyte migration → corresponding to oligodendrocyte migration during corticogenesis. NPC3 – fetal neuronal differentiation into young neurons → corresponding to cortical neurogenesis in vivo. Over the time course of differentiation, neurons expressing β-III-tubulin progressively appear in the migration zone representing approximately 20% of the mixed culture after 5 days. In line with observations in vivo, inhibition of the Notch signaling pathway during hNPC differentiation increases neuronal numbers compared to the solvent control (Koch et al., 2022). Moreover, narciclasine, an activator of Ras homolog family member A (RhoA), reduces neuronal differentiation of hNPCs cultured for 5 days in a concentration-dependent manner (Masjosthusmann et al., 2020; Blum et al., 2023). Likewise, RhoA inactivation stimulated axon regeneration and recovery of hindlimb function after spinal cord injury in mice (Dergham et al., 2002). NPC4 – neurite length, neurite area of young primary fetal neurons → corresponding to axon/dendrite formation in vivo. During the 5 days of hNPC differentiation, neurite maturation is characterized by an elongation of neurites and an increase in neurite area (Koch et al., 2022). Increase in RhoA activity caused morphological alterations in rat cortical neurons in vivo (Chen et al., 2018). In line with that, RhoA activator narciclasine reduced both neurite area and neurite length (Masjosthusmann et al., 2020). NPC5 – oligodendrocyte formation from fetal hNPCs → corresponding to oligodendrogenesis during the fetal phase of brain development. Differentiation of hNPCs over 5 days progressively generates cells expressing the oligodendrocyte-marker O4, which exhibit the typical oligodendrocyte morphology with multiple branched processes necessary to ensheath neuronal axons (Moors et al., 2009; Koch et al., 2022). Differentiation of hNPCs in the presence of the Notch inhibitor DAPT concentration-dependently decreases the percentage of O4-positive cells compared to the solvent control (Koch et al., 2022). Moreover, oligodendrocyte differentiation is negatively influenced by bone morphogenic protein (BMP) 7 (Baumann et al., 2015) and BMP2 (Masjosthusmann et al., 2018), proteins of the transforming growth factor β family. These data demonstrate that two major developmental pathways, i.e. Notch and BMP, are functional in hNPCs. Primary hNPCs are self-organized and produce auto- and paracrine cues like heparin-binding EGF-like growth factor (HB-EGF) and neuregulins that guide migration and differentiation. Moreover, they express extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins like laminin subunits, fibronectin and collagens (microarray data from Klose et al. 2021). Hence, effects concerning ECM-like adhesion defects can be assessed with this assay (Barenys et al. 2017). Various signaling cues that guide migration and differentiation processes of the neurosphere assay are summarized in Koch et al., 2022.
gtruth_answer_quality_justification: The answer provides detailed information on the features and behaviors of hNPCs in vitro, but it does not address where the test system differs from the mimicked human tissue or identify specific gaps of analogy that need to be considered. The response lacks a direct comparison between the test system and human tissue, which is essential to fully address the question.
llm_answer:
The assay uses fetal human neural progenitor cells to recapitulate early neurodevelopmental events such as radial glia migration, neuronal and oligodendrocyte migration, and early differentiation events. However, several limitations arise when comparing the in vitro system to the full complexity of developing human brain tissue. Specifically:

• The cells represent early, fetal stages of brain development. Neurons remain immature, so later events (for example, synaptogenesis and the formation of functional neuronal networks) are not reproduced.  
• Although the assay mimics migration along radial glia, it does not model proper positioning or cortical layer formation as seen in vivo.  
• Some key neurodevelopmental processes—such as neural proliferation, apoptosis, astrocyte maturation/reactivity, synaptogenesis, and network formation—are not included in the assay.  

These gaps illustrate that—while the assay gives valuable insight into early migration and differentiation—the full spectrum of later, more complex developmental processes cannot be addressed, which should be taken into account when extrapolating to human tissue responses.  
_(Sources: NPC2-5.pdf)_

Basic maintenance of the hNPCs is performed according to a standardized SOP that can be accessed in the DB‐ALM system. In summary, after thawing, the primary human neural progenitor cells (hNPCs) are expanded in a serum‑free proliferation medium (DMEM/Ham’s F12 supplemented with B27, EGF, FGF, and antibiotics) at 37°C/5% CO₂. Cells are fed by replacing half the medium every two–three days and are weekly passaged by mechanical dissociation once the neurospheres reach the acceptable size (0.2–0.5 mm). This “basic cell propagation” is maintained throughout the expansion phase prior to plating for differentiation.

The purity of the cell population is ensured by supplier‐provided characterization and in‑house quality checks. Cryopreserved neurospheres from Lonza originate from the human fetal cortex (gestational weeks 16–19) and are characterized by expression of neural stem/progenitor markers (nestin, SOX2, Ki67) in proliferating cultures and, after differentiation, by markers such as TUBB3 (neurons), GFAP (astrocytes), and O4 (oligodendrocytes). Although a specific percentage is not reported in our protocol, the acceptance criteria for the source cells include positive immunocytochemical detection of TUBB3 and GFAP after differentiation, a cell count of approximately 1.2 × 10⁶ cells/mL, and a viability of at least 20%. Batch‐to‐batch testing also involves sterility controls (free of HIV, HBV, HC), mycoplasma testing (every three months), and routine visual inspections for fungal or bacterial contamination.

For use in the assay, cells are taken from the expanded cultures once neurospheres reach a defined size (0.25–0.35 mm) after 3–4 weeks of expansion. While the SOP does not strictly restrict passage number, the protocol implies that only early‐to‐mid passages (from the initial expansion) are used because any inter‐donor differences that may affect the downstream endpoints are minimized after the first mechanical dissociation. The entire cell expansion and maintenance procedure is performed under good cell culture practice (GCCP) conditions and the assay is in line with principles of Good In Vitro Method Practice (GIVIMP) as detailed in the SOP.

Regarding cell banking, once a sufficient number of neurospheres has been expanded, cells can be cryopreserved in liquid nitrogen to generate working cell banks. Freezing stocks are prepared by aliquoting 1 × 10⁶ cells per vial (using the supplier’s recommended protocol) and are stored at –20°C for short-term use or in liquid nitrogen for long-term storage. The same cell batch is typically used throughout an experimental series (up to four weeks in differentiation experiments), but prolonged cultures necessitate fresh thawing from the prepared cell bank in order to maintain reproducibility and cell quality.

For primary cells in general, the cells are obtained commercially (here, from Lonza) as cryopreserved 3D neurospheres isolated from the human fetal brain cortex. They are pre‐characterized by the supplier for cell identity (expression of neural progenitor markers), viability (minimum 20%), and sterility (free of HIV, HBV, HC, mycoplasma, and other contaminants). Inclusion criteria include an acceptable cell count (approx. 1.2 × 10⁶ cells/mL) and confirmed marker expression (e.g. nestin, SOX2, Ki67 in proliferating cultures, and proper differentiation marker expression after differentiation), while exclusion criteria are based on failure to meet these sterility and viability benchmarks.

(Sources: NPC2-5.pdf)

Overall Workflow

 • Spheres are freshly selected (with a diameter around 0.3 mm) and re-plated onto 96‑well flat‐bottom plates pre‑coated with poly‑D‑lysine/laminin.  
 • The plating is done in differentiation medium (DMEM:Ham’s F12, 2:1) supplemented with 1% N2 and 1% penicillin/streptomycin.

──────────────────────────────
Exposure Scheme Timeline

• Day 0 (Start of Differentiation / Exposure):  
 – Freshly re-plated neurosphere (0.3 mm diameter) is embedded on poly‑D‑lysine/laminin coated well.  
 – Differentiation medium with the test compound (or solvent control) is added.  
 – The assay begins with cells in a non-confluent, spheroid state.

        [Plating + Compound Exposure Day 0]

• 0–72 Hours (Initial Exposure Period):  
 – Spheres remain in the differentiation medium with the test compound continuously present.  
 – During this period, cells initiate radial migration out of the sphere core.

• 72 Hours (Medium Change & Re-dosing):  
 – Half of the medium from each well is carefully removed and replaced with freshly prepared differentiation medium containing the same concentration of the test compound (or solvent control).  
 – This step ensures that compound exposure is maintained and that the cells receive fresh nutrients.

        [Medium Change/Re-dosing at 72h]

• 72–120 Hours (Continued Exposure & Differentiation):  
 – The migration process continues, now in the refreshed medium.  
 – Cells further differentiate into neurons, oligodendrocytes, radial glia, etc.

• 120 Hours (End of Exposure):  
 – The assay is terminated.  
 – Endpoints are assessed:  
  • Brightfield imaging is used (e.g., for radial glia migration measured at 72 h and 120 h).  
  • The wells are fixed and immunocytochemistry (using Hoechst, β‑III‑tubulin and O4 staining) is performed to quantify neuronal and oligodendrocyte differentiation, neurite outgrowth, and other endpoints.

Key Critical Points

• Cells used in the assay are freshly re-plated spheres rather than a confluent monolayer.  
• Coating: Plates must be pre‑coated with poly‑D‑lysine/laminin to provide the appropriate extracellular matrix for migration.  
• Differentiation medium is critical—it does not include growth factors (EGF, FGF) but is supplemented with 1% N2 and penicillin/streptomycin.

Primary endpoints of the NPC2-5 assay are the neurodevelopment‐specific measures, which include:

• Radial glia migration (measured at both 72 hours and 120 hours as the migration distance in µm from the sphere core)  
• Neuronal migration, defined as the mean distance of all neurons from the sphere core after 120 hours  
• Oligodendrocyte migration, defined similarly for oligodendrocytes  
• Neuronal differentiation, determined as the percentage of β‑III-tubulin–positive neurons among all cells (Hoechst‐positive nuclei) after 120 hours  
• Neurite outgrowth parameters (neurite length and neurite area) assessed after 120 hours  
• Oligodendrocyte differentiation, based on the percentage of O4‑positive cells after 120 hours  

Cytotoxicity is not the primary endpoint; it is measured as a secondary endpoint together with cell viability. Secondary endpoints include:

• Cell number (total count of Hoechst-positive nuclei)  
• Cytotoxicity (assessed via LDH release assays at 72 and 120 hours)  
• Viability (determined via mitochondrial activity using a resazurin reduction assay at 120 hours)

For normalization of the primary endpoints, the test system uses reference endpoints such as the cell number. In practice, neuronal and oligodendrocyte differentiation endpoints are expressed as a percentage relative to the total cell number measured in the migration area (using Hoechst-staining). In addition, cytotoxicity and viability data serve as unspecific endpoints that help distinguish specific developmental effects from general cell health impairment.

gtruth_answer: Primary endpoints: 1 . Radial glia migration 72 h is assessed as migration distance in µm from the edge of the sphere core to the edge of the migration area based on brightfield images of each well (Figure 3). Therefore, each plate is scanned after 72 h in culture in an automated high content imaging device under 5% CO2 and 37°C. Images are exported and the sphere size in four directions is measured manually using ImageJ. All other primary endpoints are assessed based on an ICC staining image for each sphere. Therefore, cells are fixated after 120 h in culture and an ICC staining with Hoechst for nuclei, β-III-tubulin for neurons and O4 for oligodendrocytes is performed. The plates are scanned using an automated high content imaging device and all nuclei and their positions are determined automatically based on their intensity and size. Images are imported to the Omnisphero software (https://omnisphero.com) to run the image analysis that measures the following endpoints. 2 . Radial glia migration 120h is assessed as the migration distance in µm between the sphere core and the edge of the migration area based on ICC images of Hoechst-positive nuclei. By identification of each nuclei’s position in relation to the sphere core, the migration distance can be calculated. Therefore, a density distribution mask is calculated. By scanning the images of the nuclei channel, the algorithm can determine relatively more or less dense image areas. By identifying the densest area in the image, the sphere core can be detected. For identification of the migration, it is assumed, that the nuclei density decreases with increasing distance to the sphere core. Once the density hits a pre-defined threshold, the outer boundaries are determined and the sphere itself can be mapped out in a polynomial bounding box. Derived from this box, the actual size and migration distance can be calculated for each well. 3 . Neuronal migration 120 h is the mean distance of all neurons from the edge of the sphere core in relation to the radial glia migration and is determined based on the position of each neuron (see neuronal differentiation). 4 . Oligodendrocyte migration 120 h is the mean distance of all oligodendrocytes from the edge of the sphere core in relation to the radial glia migration and is determined based on the position of each oligodendrocytes (see oligodendrocyte differentiation). 5 . Neuronal differentiation is defined as the number of all β-III-tubulin-positive cells in percent of the cell number (Hoechst-positive cells) in the migration area after 120 h of differentiation. The identification of neurons is done automatically using a convolutional neural network (CNN). Training of the CNN was done based on manually annotated experiments (Förster et al., 2021). 6 . Neurite length 120 h is the mean length in µm of all neurons (see neuronal differentiation) that are identified by the skeletonization algorithm in Omnisphero (https://omnisphero.com). 7 . Neurite area 120 h is the mean area in pixels (without nuclei) of all neurons (see neuronal differentiation) that are identified by the skeletonization algorithm in Omnisphero (https://omnisphero.com). 8 . Oligodendrocyte differentiation 120 h is defined as the number of all O4-positive cells in percent of the cell number (Hoechst-positive cells) within the migration area after 120 h of differentiation. The identification of oligodendrocytes is done automatically using a convolutional neural network (CNN). Training of the CNN was done based on manually annotated experiments (Förster et al., 2021). Secondary endpoints: 3 . Cell number is the number of all Hoechst-positive nuclei detected within the area between the sphere core and the outer boundaries of the migration area (see radial glia migration 120 h). 4 . Cytotoxicity 72/120 h is assessed as membrane integrity by measuring the amount of LDH leaked from cells with damaged plasma membranes. LDH-dependent reduction of resazurin to resorufin is measured in the supernatant of each well as fluorescence of the reaction product resorufin (relative fluorescence unit) in a multiplate reader after 72/120 h of differentiation and compound treatment. 5 . Viability 120 h is assessed as mitochondrial activity by measuring the amount of resazurin reduced to fluorescent resorufin (relative fluorescence unit) in a multiplate reader in the last two hours of the 120 h differentiation and compound treatment period.

• Radial glia migration at 72 h is measured manually in ImageJ (by measuring the sphere size in four directions) and then the mean of four replicate measures is directly entered into the AXES sheet.  
• For endpoints assessed from ICC images (radial migration at 120 h, cell number, differentiation, neurite length/area), the Omnisphero software automatically detects all Hoechst‐positive nuclei as well as marker‐positive neurons (β‑III‑tubulin) and oligodendrocytes (O4) using a convolutional neural network that was trained on manually annotated images _(Förster et al., 2021)_.  
• Neuronal differentiation is calculated as the number of β‑III‑tubulin‐positive neurons divided by the number of all Hoechst‑positive cells (multiplied by 100 for percentage). Other endpoints such as neuronal or oligodendrocyte migration are normalized to the radial glia migration distance.  
• Viability is determined by correcting the measured signal (e.g. Alamar blue assay fluorescence) for medium background, and cytotoxicity is normalized using the formula:  
  normalized response = (lysis control – response) / (lysis control – solvent control)  
• For each experiment, replicate data points are normalized to the median solvent control response to account for inter‐plate variability, and then pooled for curve fitting (using the R package drc) to determine Benchmark Concentrations (BMCs) and their confidence intervals (BMCU and BMCL) _(Source: NPC2-5.pdf)_.

Detailed algorithm for imaging endpoints in Omnisphero is as follows:  
1. Images are acquired in both brightfield and fluorescence channels (for Hoechst and cell‐type–specific markers).  
2. The software identifies nuclei by thresholding based on intensity and size. With these data, a density distribution mask is generated from the Hoechst channel.  
3. The densest region of nuclei is defined as the sphere core by fitting a polynomial bounding box around this area.  
4. Subsequently, the software determines the outer boundaries where nuclei density decreases below a pre‐defined threshold, thus delineating the migration area.  
5. Measurement algorithms then calculate:  
  a. The radial migration distance (from the sphere core to the outer edge).  
  b. The mean migration distances of neurons and oligodendrocytes based on the positions of individually identified marker‐positive cells.  
6. For neurite analysis, a skeletonization algorithm is applied on the β‑III‑tubulin–stained images to quantify neurite length (in µm or pixels) and area (in pixels, excluding nuclear regions).  

All these steps and settings are described in further detail in the SOP in DB‑ALM format (see Appendix J, Masjosthusmann et al., 2020). This ensures that machine settings, analytical standards, and data processing/normalization procedures are consistently applied and traceable throughout the assay workflow _(Sources: NPC2-5.pdf)_.

Below is a list of mechanistic control compounds (MCC) that have been used in the NPC2‐5 assay. These chemicals are considered MCC because they modify key neurodevelopmental endpoints by activating or inhibiting specific signaling pathways in a manner that is consistent with the biology underlying the assay. Their effects are reproducible and, when applied on every plate, they serve to monitor day‐to‐day test performance and help set the acceptance criteria (AC).

1. PP2 (10 µM)  
 • Role: A SRC‐family kinase inhibitor that targets the pathway regulating radial glia migration (endpoint NPC2a).  
 • Expected Response: Reduces radial glia migration to about 0–60% of solvent control values.  
 • Comment: Because inhibition of SRC kinases is known to reduce cell motility, PP2 is used routinely as a day‐to‐day control to confirm that the assay can detect a decrease in migration.  

2. EGF (20 ng/mL)  
 • Role: A growth factor acting via EGFR that affects several aspects of hNPC behavior. Although EGF stimulate proliferation and migration, its addition in this context is used as a control that leads to a decrease in neuronal differentiation (endpoint NPC3).  
 • Expected Response: Reduces neuronal differentiation to between 0 and 50% of the solvent control.  
 • Comment: Due to the biologically plausible antagonistic effect on neuronal differentiation, EGF is used on each plate to set the AC for this endpoint.  

3. BMP7 (100 ng/mL)  
 • Role: Activates the BMP signaling cascade known to promote astroglial differentiation while inhibiting oligodendrocyte formation (endpoint NPC5).  
 • Expected Response: Decreases oligodendrocyte differentiation to between 0 and 60% of the solvent control.  
 • Comment: BMP7 is run as a positive control for oligodendrocyte differentiation performance and is part of the routine quality control panel for this assay.  

4. Triton X‐100 (0.2% v/v)  
 • Role: A detergent that lyses cells and is used as a positive control for viability and cytotoxicity endpoints.  
 • Expected Response: Causes maximal release of LDH (cytotoxicity) and reduction in resazurin conversion (viability), ensuring that the assay is sensitive to changes in membrane integrity and mitochondrial activity.  

Additional MCC that have been reported and are informative in this assay system include:

5. DAPT (a Notch signaling inhibitor)  
 • Role: Inhibits Notch signaling, which has been shown to increase neuronal differentiation.  
 • Expected Response: An increase in the percentage of neuronal cells (β‐III-tubulin–positive) compared to controls.  
 • Comment: Although not routinely part of the day‐to‐day performance panel, DAPT is useful to demonstrate that modulation of the Notch pathway leads to expected changes in neuronal differentiation.

6. Narciclasine  
 • Role: Acts as a RhoA activator. Increased RhoA activity is known to reduce neurite outgrowth.  
 • Expected Response: A concentration‐dependent reduction in neurite length and neurite area (endpoint NPC4).  
 • Comment: This control further confirms that the assay is responsive to pathway activations that negatively impact neuronal morphology.

In summary, the pathway modulations do correlate with the test method responses. For example, inhibition of the SRC pathway by PP2 leads to reduced radial glia migration, whereas activation of the BMP pathway by BMP7 results in diminished oligodendrocyte differentiation. Similarly, the EGFR activation by EGF yields a decrease in neuronal differentiation, and inhibition of Notch signaling (via DAPT) increases the neuronal fraction. These responses are in line with our understanding of the underlying biology and are reproducible enough to serve as day‐to‐day controls for assay performance. Among these, PP2, EGF, and BMP7 are routinely used on every plate to confirm that the AC (e.g. migration distances, minimum percentages of neurons and oligodendrocytes) are met. 

(Sources: NPC2‐5.pdf)

The negative control in the NPC2‑5 assay is the solvent control (SC). In practice, the SC is prepared by adding the pure solvent at the same concentration as present in the highest test condition. Commonly used solvents are:

• DPBS at 2% v/v  
• ddH2O at 2% v/v

question: Does the test system have a particular apoptosis sensitivity or resistance? Is cytotoxicity hard to capture for minor cellular subpopulations? In multicellular systems, which cell population is the most sensitive? Are specific markers known for each cell population? Are there issues with distinguishing slowed proliferation from cell death? For repeated/prolonged dosing: Is early death and compensatory growth considered? For very short-term endpoints (e.g. electrophysiology measured 30 min after toxicant exposure): Is a delayed measure of cytotoxicity provided?
gtruth_answer: Differentiating hNPCs are a multicellular system consisting of radial glia, neurons (1.5-16 %), oligodendrocytes (1.5-11%) and astrocytes within the migration area. The measurement of cytotoxicity and viability therefore always represents all cells within the migration area. Because of the higher percentage of GFAP-positive radial glia and astrocytes, these two cell types are overrepresented in the assessment of cytotoxicity and viability. The measure of cell viability assessed by the Alamar blue assay (mitochondrial reductase activity) strongly depends on the number of cells in the migration area. Therefore, a reduction in cell number either due to a reduced migration distance or a lower cell number in the migration area will lead to a reduction in the Alamar blue signal despite the cell viability is not necessarily affected (Figure 3 in Nimtz et al. 2019). Therefore, as soon as the migration distance or cell number in the migration area are reduced, the Alamar blue (viability) assay is not used as a measure for viability, but the cytotoxicity assay (based on LDH release) is taken as a reference for the specific DNT endpoints to determine if the effect is specific or not.
gtruth_answer_quality_justification: The answer provides some relevant information about the multicellular system and the challenges in measuring cytotoxicity and viability, particularly highlighting the overrepresentation of certain cell types and the limitations of the Alamar blue assay. However, it does not fully address all aspects of the question, such as specific apoptosis sensitivity or resistance, issues with distinguishing slowed proliferation from cell death, or considerations for repeated/prolonged dosing and short-term endpoints. The response lacks completeness and clarity on these points.
llm_answer:
1. The test system does not specifically assess apoptosis. In fact, NPC apoptosis is listed among the neurodevelopmental processes that are not represented by this assay (see “Neurodevelopmental processes not represented by this test method,” page 154).  
2. Cytotoxicity endpoints (based on LDH release and Alamar blue viability) capture the overall response of all cells within the migration area. Because the culture is dominated by GFAP‐positive radial glia/astrocytes, subtle changes within small “minor” subpopulations (e.g. the neurons or oligodendrocytes) may be masked by the aggregate signal (see “Features relevant for cytotoxicity testing,” page 140).  
3. Concerning sensitivity, the viability and cytotoxicity readouts mostly reflect the dominant cell populations in the migration area – that is, the radial glia and astrocytes. There is no detailed analysis provided that specifically pinpoints one minor subpopulation as most sensitive over the others.  
4. For cell identification, the assay uses specific markers: neurons are identified by β‑III-tubulin; oligodendrocytes by O4; astrocytes by GFAP; and radial glia by nestin (and additionally GFAP and Ki‑67 for proliferative status) (see “Characterization and definition of source cells” and subsequent sections on cell differentiation, pages 127–133).  
5. The documentation stresses a known challenge: distinguishing between a reduction in cell number (which can result from either slowed migration/proliferation or from cell death) is not straightforward. For instance, a lower Alamar blue signal might occur due to fewer cells present as a consequence of reduced migration rather than actual loss of viability. Thus, when migration or cell count is reduced, the LDH‐based cytotoxicity measure is used as the reference endpoint (see “Features relevant for cytotoxicity testing,” page 140).  
6. Regarding repeated or prolonged dosing, the assay protocol involves compound exposure over 120 h with a feeding step after 72 h. There is no explicit procedure described that accounts for early cell death followed by compensatory growth over the exposure period.  
7. Finally, for very short-term endpoints such as electrophysiological measurements conducted 30 minutes after toxicant exposure, the assay does not include a provision for an early/delayed cytotoxicity measure; cytotoxicity and viability are assessed only at the 72 h and 120 h time points (see “Test method exposure scheme and endpoints,” pages 135–137).

(Sources: NPC2-5.pdf)

Stock solutions are prepared by diluting the compound in the solvent (e.g. DMSO) in a concentration that allows the preparation of the highest test concentration without exceeding the highest acceptable solvent concentration (see 0). For DMSO the highest acceptable solvent concentration is 0.1% which means that the stock concentration needs to be at least 1000x higher than the highest test concentration. Stock solutions in non-sterile solvents (e.g. water or PBS) have to be sterile filtrated using a sterile syringe filter (diameter 0.2 µm). Adsorption to the filter needs to be considered. Stock solutions are aliquoted and stored at -20°C. A stock solution is not thawed more than three times. For the preparation of the test condition the stock solution is diluted to the highest test concentration (default 1:1000) in differentiation medium. All following dilutions are prepared by serial dilutions of the highest concentration in differentiation medium containing solvent (in the concentration of the highest test concentration). The default serial dilution is 1:3 which covers a concentration range from e.g. 20 µM to 27 nM (729-fold). Depending on the desired concentration range, the dilution can be changed to 1:2, 1:5, 1:10 or other. The SC is prepared by adding the solvent to differentiation media in the same concentration as the highest test concentration. 100 µL of the compound dilutions and the SC are added to a 96-well plate (Figure 4). The serial dilution can also be prepared directly in the 96 well plates. hNPCs are added to each well after a 15 to 30 min equilibration period at 37°C and 5 % CO2. To subtract the background fluorescence of the phenol red-containing medium, 4 wells with medium only (Background, medium without cells, Figure 5) are prepared for the viability and cytotoxicity assays.Figure 5 Plating Scheme. The solvent control depends on the solvent of the compound that is tested. 7 compound concentrations are plated in a serial dilution from lowest (left) to highest (right) concentration. Lysis control (4 replicates for each timepoint, 72h and 120h) and background control (4 replicates) are used for the viability and cytotoxicity assays. Endpoint-specific controls for radial glia migration (PP2), neuronal differentiation (EGF) and oligodendrocyte differentiation (BMP7) are performed on each experimental plate (4 replicates each).

The assay protocol uses precise volumes and calibrated liquid handling to ensure reproducibility. For example, compound dilutions are prepared in differentiation medium and then 100 µL of each dilution (including the solvent control) is dispensed into individual wells of 96‐well flat‐bottom plates. A liquid handling system or pipettes are employed to minimize pipetting variation, with outer wells often filled with water to mitigate edge effects. _(Source: NPC2-5.pdf)_

Compound stocks are prepared at a concentration at least 1000× above the highest test concentration so that, when diluted, the solvent (typically DMSO—in addition to alternatives such as DPBS, ddH₂O, or MeOH) does not exceed the maximum acceptable concentration (0.1% v/v for DMSO). When compounds are dissolved in non‐sterile solvents, the stock solutions are sterile‐filtrated through 0.2 µm syringe filters to ensure sterility. The stock solutions are aliquoted and stored at −20°C, and they are not allowed to undergo more than three freeze–thaw cycles. _(Source: NPC2-5.pdf)_

For the dilution process, the highest test concentration is first prepared by diluting the stock into differentiation medium. Subsequent dilutions are carried out as serial dilutions—commonly in a 1:3 dilution series—ensuring that each step maintains the same final solvent concentration as the highest test concentration. This careful approach also helps to confirm the solubility of each compound in the test medium, with solubility either established beforehand via databases/literature or confirmed experimentally. _(Source: NPC2-5.pdf)_

Regarding the final addition to the test system, after compound dilutions (100 µL per well) have been added to the pre-coated 96‐well plates (coated with poly‑D‑lysine/laminin), the plates are allowed to equilibrate for 15–30 minutes at 37°C and 5% CO₂. Only then are the human neural progenitor cells (hNPCs) added. Medium exchanges (e.g. at day 3) involve replacing half of the medium with freshly prepared test condition solutions to maintain proper compound exposure. _(Source: NPC2-5.pdf)_

In summary, the process encompasses:  
• Using defined volumes (typically 100 µL per well) dispensed into 96-well plates with automated or manual pipetting systems.  
• Maintaining assay temperature (37°C, 5% CO₂) and controlled lighting conditions during incubation and imaging.  
• Diluting the compounds in differentiation medium (DMEM/Ham’s F12, 2:1 with additional supplements) in a serial dilution scheme while adhering to a rigid solvent concentration limit (e.g. 0.1% DMSO).  
• Preparing compound stocks at ≥1000× concentration, verifying solubility (via pilot or literature data), sterile filtering if required, aliquoting, and storing them at −20°C.  
• Adding the test compounds to the test system by pre-dispensing compound dilutions into the designated wells and then adding the cells after a brief equilibration period, as well as updating media during the culture period to maintain exposure.  

Each step is carefully designed to minimize variability and assure that compound exposures occur under tightly regulated conditions. _(Source: NPC2-5.pdf)_

Sources of variation: - Pipetting steps: Each pipetting step is a source of variation. As pipetting errors add up in each washing step, there is variation in the dilution of blocking solution and antibodies. - NPC differentiation: The biological variation between the differentiation of different NPC spheres cannot be controlled and can lead to variations in the endpoints neuronal and oligodendrocyte differentiation. Known Pitfalls: - Spill over from the lysis control wells to other wells can happen and needs to be controlled by the operator. llm_answer:
Problematic compounds include:  
• Volatile compounds, highly lipophilic compounds (with high KOW), and compounds with low solubility in the established solvents because they may precipitate or require modification of the exposure protocol.  
• Fluorescent compounds may interfere with the readouts of viability and cytotoxicity assays, as their intrinsic fluorescence could obscure the detection of assay signals.  
   
Experimental variables that are hard to control include:  
• Variability introduced during multiple pipetting steps (e.g. during ICC staining washes and compound dilution steps) which can lead to errors in reagent volumes and inconsistent antibody dilutions.  
• The cell differentiation variability inherent to the maturation and sphere selection process, where slight differences in sphere size or handling can affect migration and differentiation endpoints.  
• Fluorescence interference from the medium components (like phenol red) and the test compounds themselves, which complicates background subtraction for viability and cytotoxicity measurements.  
   
Critical handling steps during assay execution include:  
• Ensuring that the poly-D-lysine/laminin coating is performed correctly and that coated plates are not used beyond 7 days at 4°C as improper coating can negatively affect cell migration and differentiation.  
• Minimizing the re-opening of incubators and avoiding vibrations to prevent sphere aggregation.  
• Careful pipetting during medium exchange and ICC staining—especially to avoid spillover from lysis control wells (which, if not properly emptied and refilled with water, may contaminate neighboring wells) and to maintain consistent coverage of spheres with PBS during washes.  
• Rapid dilution of DMSO in the thawing medium to protect cell health.  
   
Robustness issues and known pitfalls include:  
• Operator variability during manual pipetting and sphere selection, which may lead to noticeable inter-well or inter-experiment variability.  
• Variability introduced by differences in consumables (such as batch effects with FGF that contains serum albumin) or plate formats (edge effects, for example, require outer wells to be filled with water).  
• Possible mistakes such as spillover from lysis control wells, inconsistent washing during ICC staining (leading to variable antibody concentrations), and inadequate handling of spheres (e.g. not ensuring they are always covered by PBS during multiple washing steps).  
   
All these details are described and discussed in the document (Sources: NPC2‑5.pdf).

3. NPC2c – assessing oligodendrocyte migration (database name: “NPC2c_DNT_hNPC_mig_120h_20200317v1.1”).  
4. NPC3 – assessing neuronal differentiation (database name: “NPC3_DNT_hNPC_diff_120h_20200317v1.1”).

Proliferating, 3‑day differentiated, and 5‑day differentiated hNPCs have been profiled to capture changes in key neurodevelopmental processes such as migration, differentiation, and signaling pathway modulation (e.g. BMP, Notch, and EGF signaling). This omics characterization provides an alternative endpoint that complements the phenotypic (imaging) readouts of the current assay.

The assay raw data are first collected either as numerical readouts (e.g. relative fluorescence units from viability/cytotoxicity measurements) or as image‐derived values (e.g. migration distances, cell numbers, neurite metrics from ICC images) and are then transferred into an AXES sheet. The following steps are applied:

1. Background Correction – For endpoints measured via a multiplate reader (e.g. viability or cytotoxicity assays), values from wells containing medium only (“background wells”) are used so that the background fluorescence is subtracted from each response value. For example, the raw viability value (RFU) gets adjusted by subtracting the medium-only (background) RFU.

2. Data Transfer – Raw numbers are imported into the AXES sheets. In the case of endpoints based on image analysis (migration, differentiation, neurite length/area), the data are exported as CSV files from the automated Omnisphero software and then manually or automatically pasted into the AXES sheet alongside manually measured values (e.g. migration in µm measured in ImageJ for radial glia migration at 72 h).

3. Normalization to Solvent Control – Each replicate’s response is normalized to the median value of the solvent control (SC) in that experiment. For instance, endpoints such as neuronal differentiation are calculated as the percentage of neurons (number of β‑III-tubulin‐positive cells divided by total Hoechst-positive cells ×100). Similarly, migration endpoints like neuronal migration are expressed as a ratio relative to the radial glia migration (i.e. mean neuronal migration divided by radial glia migration ×100).

4. Re‐normalization to the Starting Point – The curve’s starting point is determined, and all normalized response values are then re‐normalized by dividing by the starting point value and multiplying by 100. This ensures that the concentration–response curve begins at 100% for the lowest (assumed non‐effect) concentration.

5. Curve Fitting and Statistical Analysis – The normalized data are then processed using an R‑based tool (using the “drc” package as implemented in the Fritsche‐lab CRStats tool) for non‐linear curve fitting. Several models are tested, and the optimal curve is chosen based on Akaike’s information criterion. From these fitted curves, summary parameters such as EC₅₀ (or other effective concentration estimates), benchmark concentrations (BMCs) with defined Benchmark Responses (BMR, e.g. 10% or 30% change), as well as upper and lower confidence limits (BMCU and BMCL) are derived. The BMCs can also serve as points of departure (PoD). For cytotoxicity endpoints, a slight variation is used: the response is normalized as “normalized response = (lysis control – response)/(lysis control – solvent control)” to account for maximal cell lysis.

6. Calculation of Ratios – Finally, additional ratios (e.g. neuronal migration relative to radial glia migration, oligodendrocyte migration relative to the migration distance of the entire nucleus population) are calculated using the formulas provided in the assay description.

This systematic pre‑processing—from background correction, data transfer, normalization to solvent control, re‑normalization to the starting point, non‑linear curve fitting with the “drc” R package, and final calculation of ratios/summary parameters—ensures that summary data such as EC₅₀, BMC values, ratios, and PoD are derived consistently from the raw assay measurements.  
_(Source: NPC2-5.pdf)_

For the cytotoxicity assays the following normalization is used instead of the normalization to the SC. Here again each response value is normalized using the median of the lysis control and the median of the solvent control. lysis control − response normalized response = lysis control − solvent control The R package drc is used to calculate the optimal curve-fit for each experiment (https://github.com/iuf- duesseldorf/fritsche-lab-CRStats; Keßel et al. (pre-print at BioRxiv; doi: 10.1101/2022.10.18.512648). For calculations of curve fits and BMCs, the data from independent experiments is pooled (median of all replicate values for one concentration). Several non-linear models are run with the concentration response data of each endpoint and the Akaike´s information criterion is used to determine the best fit. For re-normalization of the data, the response value of the curves starting point is determined and used to re-normalize all response values. Therefore, each mean response value is divided by the starting point of the curve and multiplied by 100. For the re-normalized response values the curve fitting is repeated to produce the final concentration response curve. For deriving a reference point (RP) or point of departure (Pod) the Benchmark Concentration (BMC) approach, as recommended by the EFSA Scientific Committee (Hardy et al., 2017), is applied. The BMC approach makes use of all data points that define the fitted concentration response curve. Thereby, the BMC is defined as the concentration that is associated with a specific change in response, the Benchmark Response (BMR). The BMR is a value of effect size and should be defined as an effect size that is higher than the general variability of the measured endpoint. The BMR is therefore determined based on the variability of the respective endpoint. BMR for NPC2-5: Primary DNT specific endpoints of the test method are: radial glia migration 72 h (NPC2a) radial glia migration 120h (NPC2a) neuronal migration 120 h (NPC2b) oligodendrocyte migration 120h (NPC2c) BMR30 neuronal differentiation 120 h (NPC3) neurite length 120 h (NPC4) neurite area 120 h (NPC4) BMR10 BMR10 BMR30 BMR30 BMR30 BMR30 oligodendrocyte differentiation 120h (NPC5) BMR30 Secondary endpoints are: cell number 120 h BMR30 cytotoxicity 72 h BMR10 cytotoxicity 120 h BMR10 viability 120 h BMR30 Based on the BMR and the concentration response curve, the evaluation tool calculates the BMC, as well as upper and lower confidence limits (BMCU and BMCL respectively) based on the predict function in the R package drc. The predict function calculates the prediction bands around the concentration response curve based on the deviation between independent experiments and gives an estimation of the area that is expected to enclose 95% of future data points. The BMCL is thereby defined as the intersection of the lower band and the BMR while the BMCU is defined as the intersection of the upper band and the BMR. The data from the assay are processed in several steps before arriving at a summary result. First, raw data (from the viability, cytotoxicity, migration, differentiation, etc.) are normalized to the solvent control, and for many endpoints, then re‐normalized by dividing by the response value at the starting point of the curve (ENV/CBC/MONO(2023)13, pp. 146–147). Next, the concentration–response curves are modeled by fitting several non‐linear models (e.g. a four‑parameter logistic model—which is essentially an LL.4 parameter fit) using an R‐based tool (CRStats) that incorporates the R package drc. In this process, the best fit is selected based on criteria such as the Akaike information criterion (ENV/CBC/MONO(2023)13, p. 147).

For uncertainty estimation, a benchmark concentration (BMC) approach is applied. The R package’s predict function is used to generate 95% confidence intervals (CI) for the BMC, which provides uncertainty measures (BMCL and BMCU). In cases where no effect is seen (non‐cytotoxicity or no-effect conditions) or when the upper limit spans above the tested concentration range, expert judgment is applied. For endpoints that are difficult to fit—such as those with non‐monotonic curve shapes or other complex behaviors—the usual mathematical fit (e.g. the logistic model) might not capture the full curve shape. In these instances, additional testing, adjusting the concentration range, or relying on expert review of the data is used to decide if the observed effect is a true hit or an artifact (ENV/CBC/MONO(2023)13, pp. 146–151).

Thus, overall:
• Data are normalized (to SC and the starting point), then curve‐fitted using several non‐linear models (typically a LL.4 parameter logistic model) by means of an R-based setup (CRStats/drc).
• Uncertainty is quantified via 95% CI for the BMC (with BMCL and BMCU calculated using R’s predict function).
• In cases of non‐cytotoxicity, no effect, or non-monotonic curves, uncertainty is dealt with by additional statistical significance testing (e.g. Tukey HSD) and expert judgment to ensure the correct classification of the compound’s effect.

(Sources: ENV/CBC/MONO(2023)13, pp. 146–151)

gtruth_answer: Primary hNPCs are isolated from the fetal brain and can be used to model neurodevelopmental processes like migration of radial glia, neurons and oligodendrocytes, neurite outgrowth and differentiation into neurons and oligodendrocytes within this test method. The test system therefore measures adverse events in the young (fetal) developing brain. Thereby, the biological processes that are modeled are: 1. radial glia cell migration (NPC2a) 2. migration of young cortical neurons (NPC2b) 3. oligodendrocyte migration (NPC2c) 4. fetal neuronal differentiation into young neurons (NPC3) 5. neurite outgrowth of young fetal neurons (NPC4) 6. oligodendrocyte formation of fetal NPC (NPC5) The toxicological events that are modeled include events that impact the above-mentioned biological processes in any direction (increase or decrease). Thereby, neurodevelopmental processes represented by the NPC2-NPC5 assay are guided by a variety of pathways known to contribute to the respective processes in vivo as assessed by hNPC exposure to in vivo relevant signaling pathway modulators (summarized in Table13, Masjosthusmann et al. 2020; Koch et al., 2022). All the endpoints can be assessed in a high content format within one experiment due to the multi-cellularity and high developmental dynamic of the neurospheres. In addition, the strength of the system is that it allows KE-based assessment of human neurodevelopment without the need to perform species extrapolation. Moreover, the self-organized mixed culture system contains cell-cell interactions e.g. via gap junction channels as cells die when cell-cell communication is blocked by gap junction blockers (unpublished observations). Hence, the system is superior to single-cell 2D systems, since due to its nature it mimics a multitude of neurodevelopmental processes. One limitation of the hNPC model is the restricted timing. These endpoints represent early processes of neurodevelopment during the fetal period. Neurons stay immature hence later processes like synaptogenesis cannot be studied. Moreover, correct positioning, like one can study in vivo with cortical layering, cannot be studied here, since the assay mimics cortical radial glia and neuronal migration but does not cortical layer formation. The test method predicts the hazard of a chemical to induce developmental neurotoxicity by causing neurophysiological, functional and behavioral changes in the developing nervous system.

The scientific rationale is based on the idea that measuring key neurodevelopmental processes in human fetal neural progenitor cells (hNPCs) in vitro can provide a mechanistic link to in vivo adverse outcomes related to neurodevelopment. In this assay, cells derived from the human fetal cortex are used to model several interrelated processes which, if disrupted, are known to impair brain development and ultimately lead to cognitive dysfunction. (Source: NPC2-5.pdf)

Specifically:

• Toxicological target: The assay focuses on the developing brain – using primary human neural progenitor cells from the fetal cortex (GW16–19) as the target system.

• Biological processes modelled: The assay reflects critical developmental processes such as:
 – Radial glia migration (NPC2a)
 – Neuronal and oligodendrocyte migration (NPC2b and NPC2c)
 – Neuronal differentiation (NPC3)
 – Neurite outgrowth (neurite length and area; NPC4)
 – Oligodendrocyte differentiation (NPC5)  
These processes are crucial for proper cortical organization and connectivity. (Source: NPC2-5.pdf)

• Toxicological events modelled: The assay evaluates disturbances in cell migration and differentiation (including changes in neurite length/area), as well as general endpoints such as cell viability and cytotoxicity. Disruption in these endpoints can indicate adverse events such as impairments in cell health, altered differentiation programs, and defective cell–cell contacts, all of which could contribute to developmental neurotoxicity. • Related (human) adverse outcome: When disrupted, the modeled processes can lead to altered brain development and, in vivo, may result in cognitive dysfunction. (Source: NPC2-5.pdf)

• Predicted hazard: The test method is designed to predict hazards that have the potential to interfere with neurodevelopment by affecting migration, differentiation, or neurite outgrowth. Thus, it is aimed at identifying chemical compounds that may cause developmental neurotoxicity (DNT) by disrupting these cellular events. (Source: NPC2-5.pdf)

gtruth_answer: Two prediction models (PM) are applied for the NPC2-5 assay. One PM for a downregulation (PM downregulation) and one PM for an upregulation (PM upregulation) in cell differentiation and migration. PM down regulation The PM uses hit definition based on comparison of the confidence intervals (CI) for the BMC of the DNT- specific endpoint (BMCs) and the unspecific endpoint (cytotoxicity/viability; BMCus). Thereby the following four hit classifications apply: “no hit” The compound is not defined as hit. “specific hit”: The compound is defined as hit and the CI’s do not overlap, meaning that the upper confidence limit of the specific endpoint (BMCUs) is lower than the lower confidence limit of the unspecific endpoint (BMCLus). The compound is defined as hit and the CI of the specific endpoint overlaps by less than or equal to 10% with the CI of the unspecific endpoint. The compound is defined as hit and the CI of the specific endpoint overlaps by more than 10% with the CI of the unspecific endpoints. “borderline hit”: “unspecific hit” The compound is classified as a hit, if the concentration response curve generates a BMC and if the CI is within the test range. In case the CI spans above the test range, the compound is only classified as hit, if the highest test concentration is significantly different from the lowest test concentration. The adjusted significance (p<0.05) is thereby determined using a Tukey HSD test. The decision process for the prediction model is described in the flow chart in Figure 11. Figure 11: Decision tree for the PM for downregulation applied for test method NPC2-5. Overview of the decisions leading to the classification of a compound in one of four categories: “no hit”, “specific hit”, “borderline hit” and “unspecific hit”. Specific consideration for the prediction model: In case no confidence limits are available for the unspecific endpoint because the BMR is not reached, the BMCLus is assumed to be the highest tested concentration. If the CI of the specific endpoint spans above the test range for a compound identified as “hit” based on statistical significance, expert judgement is applied to define, if the “hit” is specific or unspecific. Therefore, all datapoints of the unspecific and specific endpoint of the highest test concentration are compared. If these data points do not overlap, the compound is classified as “specific hit”, otherwise as “unspecific hit”. In general, BMCs based on the same BMR are compared (e.g. BMC30us vs BMC30s). In case the BMC30us is not available for an endpoint that allows the generation of a BMC10us, the BMC10us is used instead. If the classification of this comparison is “unspecific hit”, the compound will be flagged as “check manually“ as the BMC10us is lower than the BMC30us leading to a higher probability of a false classification. To avoid such false classification expert judgement is needed. Compounds can also be flagged as “check manually”, if the classification based on the viability is different from the classification based on the cytotoxicity and if the confidence interval is very wide (BMCU/BMCL > 25), which means a high uncertainty for the BMC estimation. In both cases expert judgement is needed to decide on the classification. The expert judgement is an individual decision process, that accounts for effect size, curve progression, statistical significance and overall standard deviation. If the concentration response curves do not give enough information for decision by expert judgement, additional testing or testing in a different concentration range should be performed. For compounds that reduce the cell number or radial glia migration the viability is not used as unspecific endpoint. The reason is that an effect in both endpoints indirectly affects cell viability. In this case only the cytotoxicity is used for the classification. PM upregulation In contrast to the PM for downregulation, the PM for upregulation is based on a hit definition without the comparison of confidence intervals (CI) between the specific and unspecific endpoint. The reason is that specific and unspecific endpoint do not have the same relationship during an induction compared to a reduction in the endpoint. A loss in general cell health will likely result in an effect in e.g cell migration or differentiation, while an induction in cell health (measured as mitochondrial activity) does not necessarily increase these endpoints. The following three hit classifications apply: “no hit” The compound is not defined as hit. “specific hit”: The compound is defined as hit and the effect is not an artifact due to loss in cell health. “unspecific hit” The compound is defined as hit in only the unspecific endpoints. The compound is classified as hit, if the concentration response curve generates a BMC and if the CI is within the test range. In case the CI spans above the test range, the compound is only classified as hit, if the highest test concentration is significantly different form the lowest test concentration. The adjusted significance (p<0.05) is thereby determined using a Tukey HSD test. The decision process for the prediction model is described in the flow chart in figure 7. Figure 7: Decision tree for the PM for upregulation applied for test method NPC2-5. Overview of the decisions leading to the classification of a compound in one of three categories: “no hit”, “specific hit”, and “unspecific hit”. In case a compound is classified as hit together with a reduction in an unspecific endpoint, it needs to be clarified if the induction is a specific effect or an artifact due to a loss in cell viability or an increase in cytotoxicity. Therefore, expert judgement is applied which accounts for effect size, curve progression, statistical significance, overall standard deviation but also morphological changes of the spheres. Expert judgement is additionally applied if the confidence interval is very wide (BMCU/BMCL > 25) which means a high uncertainty for the BMC estimation.

For dichotomized endpoints (i.e. a binary toxic versus non‐toxic outcome), the prediction model is set up using a comparison of the concentration–response curve–derived benchmark concentration (BMC) and its 95% confidence interval for a specific DNT endpoint versus that of an unspecific endpoint (usually cytotoxicity or viability). In the “PM downregulation” model the compound is considered a “specific hit” (toxic) when the upper confidence limit of the specific endpoint (e.g. neuronal differentiation, which is set with a BMR of 30% change for NPC3) is lower than the lower confidence limit of the unspecific endpoint (e.g. cytotoxicity using a BMR of 10%; see pages 148–150). A “borderline hit” is defined when there is an overlap of ≤10% between the two confidence intervals. In contrast, if the two confidence intervals overlap by more than 10%, the compound is classified as an “unspecific hit” (suggesting that the effects are likely due to general cell health rather than a DNT‐specific effect).  
_(Source: NPC2-5.pdf, pages 148–151)_

2. For pseudo-dichotomized outcomes (i.e. those with three categories: toxic, borderline, and non-toxic), the borderline range is defined based on a limited overlap (≤10%) between the confidence intervals for the specific DNT endpoint and the unspecific endpoint. Thus, compounds falling into this borderline zone do not unambiguously separate from the solvent control but also do not display a complete shift comparable to the “specific hit”.  
_(Source: NPC2-5.pdf, pages 148–151)_

3. For multi‐class or continuous outcomes (endpoints such as migration distance, neuronal differentiation, neurite length, etc.), the definitions use continuous quantitative measures. For example, the BMR thresholds for primary DNT endpoints are set as follows:  
  • Radial glia migration (72 h and 120 h): BMR = 10% change  
  • Neuronal migration, oligodendrocyte migration, neuronal differentiation, neurite length/area, oligodendrocyte differentiation: BMR = 30% change  
The rationale for these thresholds is twofold. Mathematically, the BMR is chosen to be larger than the inherent variability of the measured endpoint (for example, differences that exceed the baseline variability or a multiple of the standard deviation) and is also set on a biological basis to represent a change that is likely toxicologically relevant (for instance, a ≥30% reduction/increase in a key neurodevelopmental process). In some cases, additional endpoints, such as cell viability, are not interpreted in isolation because a reduction in viability may simply reflect a lower cell count rather than a selective adverse functional change.  
_(Source: NPC2-5.pdf, pages 147 and 148)_

Rationale and Toxicological Basis for the Thresholds:
• The thresholds are set so that the effect size (BMR) is larger than the inter‐ and intra-experimental variability. For example, for radial glia migration the acceptance range is defined (e.g. 700–1500 µm at 72 h), and the BMR (10% change) reflects a deviation that is statistically robust relative to biological variation.  
• There is also a biological rationale since the NPC2-5 assay is designed to capture key neurodevelopmental processes (e.g. migration and differentiation) so that a shift beyond the BMR level is considered likely to contribute to cognitive dysfunction in the developing brain.  
_(Source: NPC2-5.pdf, pages 147–149)_

Limitations of the Prediction Model:
• The prediction model, while statistically robust, can be limited by variability introduced by technical factors (e.g. pipetting errors, ICC staining variability) and biological heterogeneity inherent in primary hNPC cultures.  
• In cases where the confidence intervals are very wide or span above the test range, expert judgment is required for classifying a hit.  
• Not all neurotoxicity modes of action are covered by the endpoints measured in this assay; hence, the assay is best used as part of an integrated testing battery.  
• The model may miss compounds whose effects are mediated by pathways not directly assessed by these endpoints.  
_(Source: NPC2-5.pdf, pages 148–151 and 156)_

Hit Definition in Screening Mode:
When used in screening mode, a “hit” is defined as a compound for which the concentration–response curve yields a BMC within the test range along with a statistically significant separation from the control (e.g. as determined by a Tukey HSD test). In screening, a hit is flagged when the measured “specific” endpoint (post-normalization to the control) exceeds the preset BMR threshold (either 10% or 30%, depending on the endpoint) while maintaining a low overlap with unspecific endpoints.  
_(Source: NPC2-5.pdf, pages 148–151)_

In summary, the threshold settings are based on both statistical criteria (confidence intervals and variability measurements) and toxicological relevance (selected % changes that reflect biological adversity). The prediction model classifies compounds as “no hit,” “borderline hit,” “unspecific hit,” or “specific hit,” with the latter indicating toxicity if the specific neurodevelopmental endpoints are affected beyond the benchmark response while general cell health is not proportionately compromised.
